results.title: Arthur Boyd: testament of a painter
results.creator_credit: Don Bennetts, Film Victoria, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Don Bennetts Films
results.brief_description: A biographical documentary on one of Australia’s most prolific artists, Arthur Boyd. A charming, gentle, compassionate man, Arthur Boyd was born in 1920 in Murrumbeena, Melbourne, into a family of artists - a family who was known for its eccentricities and stern religious background. In this film we see Arthur chatting with his two young grandsons, providing them with a historical glimpse into their family background through old photographs and stories which have been passed down through the generations, along with his own personal memories of growing up in such a dynasty of “painters, potters, and dreamers”. Boyd was a figurative artist whose work focused on the human condition within the Australian landscape and although he did spend many years out of Australia in London and Europe, his works always retained the Australian spirit. Through stills, home movies, interviews, personal narratives and examples of his paintings, this program endeavours to give an overview of Boyd’s evolving journey through the decades, from his early aspirations to being an actor to finally becoming a serious painter and sculptor. We also see Boyd at work in 1993 as he prepares for a retrospective Exhibition to be held at the Art Gallery of New South Wales. Arthur Boyd has left his legacy to the Australian people by bequeathing three of his properties as a gift to the nation, including the well-known “Bundanon” property which houses artists in residence, an education centre and several of Boyd’s paintings. Arthur Boyd died on 24 April 1999. This superb documentary is a testimony to a truly great artist. Narrated by Oliver Streeton.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Bennetts, Film Victoria, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Don Bennetts Films

results.title: Arthur Boyd: figures in a landscape (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A fascinating program that looks at the painting of Australian artist, Arthur Boyd. For the purposes of this peacefully but not passively photographed documentary, Arthur Boyd completed two different paintings of the same scene, an interior and exterior interpretation of bathers and water-skiers who regularly churn up the tranquillity outside his door, explaining as he works, his inspiration and intention.

results.title: Arrivederci Roma
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Richard Zotorski and Geoffrey Wright
results.brief_description: Marinelli (Robert Forza) is a new immigrant to Australia who experiences difficulties when confronted with the harshness of the Anglo-saxon culture during a swimming lesson. With an inability to speak English, Marinelli is plunged into the deep end of the pool and cultural survival. Directed by Geoffrey Wright known mostly for ‘Romper Stomper’ and ‘Metal Skin’. Set in the City Baths, Melbourne.

results.title: Around the World with Dot
results.brief_description: In “Around the World with Dot” there are carefully interwoven elements of history, geography, bushlore, conservation and social studies with the animated action so that children of all ages will be educated while being entertained. Rated: G
results.description: In “Around the World with Dot” there are carefully interwoven elements of history, geography, bushlore, conservation and social studies with the animated action so that children of all ages will be educated while being entertained. Rated: G

results.title: Around the boree log (1925)
results.creator_credit: Phil K Walsh and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Shot in the district around Goulburn, NSW near Wollondilly river, this historical silent film warmly depicts bush life in Australia in the 1870’s of early Catholic settlers as described in the poem of the title. The priest and poet, Father John O’Brien (aka Father Patrick Hartigan), appears in the film reading prose as the story begins. The humorous tale recounts his childhood experiences of childhood and education in the bush. Wonderful images include the ‘old shaky slab hut school’ and the bush salesman where the mother buys the children each a hat, humourously described…”six ugly extinguishers that fitted us too soon - six ugly upturned canisters, each one a thing of gloom”. The film was not without controversy. When the film was first screened, reactions were mixed because of its obvious Catholic bias; some distributors even refusing to screen it, seeing it as Catholic propaganda. Today, as then, the film is still a charming recollection of earlier days. With music only, no intertitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phil K Walsh and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: Around perception
results.creator_credit: Robert Verrall, Pierre Heberrt and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An early experiment in employing computers to animate film. The result is a dazzling vibration of geometric forms in vivid colour, an effect achieved by varying the speed at which alternate colours change, so producing optical illusions. In between these screen pyrotechnics there appears a simple line form gyrating in a smooth rhythm. Sound effects are created by registering sound shapes directly on the sound track of the film. Award: Buenos Aires.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Verrall, Pierre Heberrt and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Ariarne Titmus’ coach Dean Boxall on her winning gold
results.brief_description: Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. Managing to dethrone previous Olympic medallist Katie Ledecky, Titmus later spoke of the pain and years of dedication it took to win. Knowing her journey full well, no one else was more ecstatic than her coach, Dean Boxell.
results.title_for_label: Ariarne Titmus’ coach Dean Boxall on her winning gold
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. After dethroning defending champion Katie Ledecky, Titmus revealed the years of dedication it took to win, telling Sunrise: “Physically, it’s a lot of training. On the days that I’m at the pool twice a day I could be there up to seven or eight hours and Dean is there a lot longer.”

Knowing her journey full well, no one else was more ecstatic than her coach, Dean Boxell, whose enthusiastic celebration was thrust into the limelight across social media.

Boxell was captured enthusiastically dancing, punching the air, screaming in joy, and yes, air-humping the glass barrier in celebration. His vigorous outpouring almost immediately went viral, spreading across local news, Twitter and Instagram after countless Olympic viewers filmed their TV screens and shared it online. Many were right there with him, finding his gut reaction honest, endearing and typically Australian.

But others found the display over the top and offensive, leading to a backlash from some Twitter users, especially Americans. Was this something that only Australian audiences could understand? Or was this an example of inflated male privilege? Titmus certainly didn’t mind at all and was thrilled to share the moment with her fervently loyal coach, who was inspired by his favourite wrestler from childhood, Ultimate Warrior.

“He is my favourite. I used to wrestle with my brother … I loved the Ultimate Warrior,” he has said.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moment, stories ad memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. After dethroning defending champion Katie Ledecky, Titmus revealed the years of dedication it took to win. Knowing her journey full well, no one was more excited than coach Dean Boxell, whose celebration was thrust into the limelight across social media.

results.title: Are there any questions?
results.creator_credit: James Parker, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A recruiting film, filmed on location at the RAAF Base, Amberley, Queensland, promoting the role of the RAAF Shows the air force as a worthwhile employer of people in an extremely wide range of occupations, ranging from the unskilled to the highly technical.
